snippet.title: Let's have a chat ... about dying
snippet.content:
Photo: AjayTvm/Shutterstock.com
Dying to Know day, a national annual day of action dedicated to bringing to life conversations and community actions around death and dying.
It is a GroudSwell initiative to help individuals and communities take action toward end-of-life planning.
GroundSwell Project executive director Jessie Williams said "death cafes", seminars on death and dying and even art exhibitions were among the events planned nationwide for Dying to Know Day. "There are people all over Australia talking about and keen to change the current approach to death," she said. RELATED READING
DID YOU KNOW?
75% of us have not had end of life discussions 60% think we don't talk about death enough Over 70% of us die in hospital though most of us would prefer to die at home Very few of us die with an advance care plan (less than 10 percent) The number of Australians aged 65 and over will double by 2050 increasing our need to plan while well and share our wishes with our loved ones WE WANT TO ENCOURAGE ALL AUSTRALIANS TO:
develop their death literacy make their end of life plans such as a will and advance care plans share these wishes with their families get informed about end of life and death care options such as dying at home, home and community led funerals and natural burial be better equipped to support family and friends experiencing death, dying and bereavement WHAT CAN YOU DO?
Host an event in your local community or workplace and start a conversation Host a or a event Take a personal action such as writing your will or having a conversation with a loved one Sign up for a and kick start your end of life planning
